name: Gemini Rue
description: Discover a world where life is cheap, identities are bought & sold, & a quest for redemption can change the fate of a whole galaxy.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 2000, XP or Vista Processor: Pentium or higher Memory: 64 Mb RAM Hard Disk Space: 700Mb Video Card: All DirectX compatible video cards DirectX®: 5.0 or Above Sound: All DirectX compatible sound cards

reviews.review_text: I HIGHLY recommended Gemini Rue for anyone who's looking for an old fashioned point and click adventure, with challenging but fair puzzles, and a fantastic story.  Everything about the game's presentation is absorbing. It has an old film noir, Sci-Fi Blade Runner feel to it with gorgeous artwork that feels retro and fresh at the same time. The premise and feel reminds me of a story straight out of Cowboy Bebop, with twists that anyone paying attention to should enjoy. Voice acting and music (very moody and dark ambiance), was also spot on.  I really found the puzzles engaging as well. A lot of point and click adventure games I have trouble getting into simply because their 'gameplay' is either much too easy or just too vague in telling me what I am exactly supposed to be doing. I didn't think Gemini Rue had this problem. There were puzzles that were easy solve, and others I had to think about for long minutes before coming up with an answer. The Easter Eggs and achievements spread throughout the game was also a plus for me.  The only problem I had with the game was the fact that it felt too short, and that after all is said and done, the characters are technically confined to two basic areas throughout the whole game when I wished there had been more to explore... But honestly the game did take me quite a bit of time to beat, and as for the lack of a wider world, I just enjoyed it so much that I didn't want it to end.

It starts off like blade runner or snatcher, the story changes as you move through the game. Voice acting in the game was great, I liked how the voices fit with the characters and how the voice actors express emotions for them. Music in game sounds like it has a touch of vangelis in it mixed with sci fi and infiltration music.

Good pointandclick adventure with an engaging, mysterious storyline that gives you a few unexpected twists. The non-linear gameplay, while understanding it's purpose, is not my cup of tea - I simply played the section I was on until the game swapped me to the next segment. I enjoyed this game, it's my favourite genre and reminded me of the old school Lucasarts games that I grew up with (especially Beneath a Steel Sky) so it had a nostalgic feel. However I do have one huge gripe - name me another pointandclick with a combat system? ... Can't think of one? There's a *reason* for that - because it doesn't work! The combat is annoying, ungainly, ruins the atmosphere and adds nothing to the overarching themes of identity and what makes us who we are. If you are looking for an original adventure with a good story, try this one but do yourself a favour and put the combat on easy to save yourself a headache.

Experiments Lain meets Blade Runner. Just play it. You won't regret +good music!  Edit: Noticed lots of ppl complaining about 640p res.  It's retro styled game. Lots of pixels. You could make a single pixel into 4 effectively making it 1280p but what's the point? It would look the same. 640p doesn't make it any worse, better imho, you can run it on pretty much any machine. I played on a laptop and had no tech issues whatsoever.
One of the best graphic adventures that I've played in my life. I give it a 100 of 100, perfect atmosphere, good story, cyberpunk and noir style. A really good game. Hope they make a sequel

Ok, it's like Monkey Island, but in a urban sci-fi environment.  The story is well-written, and keeps the gamer intrigued, step after step. The voice acting for each character gives a very enjoyable experience.  This is a must-have in your library (and also a must-play)!

Gemini Rue is like a 90s adventure game, for good and ill. For good because it stylistically fits right beside games like Rise of the Dragon, Dreamweb and Beneath a Steel Sky. It’s nice to see the style be kept alive.  Unfortunately the game also plays like a 90s adventure game. The controls and interactions are clunky, with none of the streamlining you’d see in newer games. Something as simple as getting up on a box and climbing a ladder involves 4 clicks and 2 keyboard commands, sometimes even more.  The story almost pulls off what it’s trying to do. In terms of mood there’s nothing wrong with it. The music, sound and visuals work together well. The problem lies with the dialog, which especially towards the end don’t deliver as strongly as it needed to. It’s so close, just another few editing passes might have done it. It doesn’t ruin it, it just stumbles across the finish line. I thought the conceit of the story was done ok. It’s not the best take on the concept, as I thought Dollhouse for example did it much better. But I thought it was alright for what it is.  The game isn’t a must play. It's good, but not as brilliant as it could have been. But if you feel like playing something that's 90s style, this will deliver, pixel hunting and all.

This game is literally a mixed bag. The campaign with Az is interesting and has a nice cyberpunk feel. The campaign with Delta 6 is rather dull. The overall plot has it's moments but is kind of boring. The atmosphere is cool though. The combat is also rather deep for a point and click game. I recommend getting this game when it is less than $6 if you like cyberpunk mysteries.
A brilliant 2D old skool adventure that stands up there with the Revolution ones I used to love, definately worth a look for point and click fans.

Now this is something I call a masterpiece of in-game storytelling. Compelling all the way through with legitmate twists! The puzzles are a bit out-there and some of the actions sections can be near-impossible, but that's exactly how a classic adventure should be.

Blending elements of noir and science fiction, Gemini Rue delivers an interesting story wrapped in old-school graphics and great writing. Fans of old Sierra and Lucasarts games will feel right at home.  The atmosphere can be summed up in one word: oppressive. Rarely have I felt so unwelcome - which is good! The music and sound design are top-notch. However, the voice acting sometimes seems to be a bit flat. The pixelated (but by no means ugly) graphics definitely are a throwback to the 'golden age' of adventure games. Don't let them discourage you, the visuals aren't everything. The combat is clunky, but generally not a huge bother.  It's the puzzles that make an adventure game. In Gemini Rue they're very intuitive and neither too easy nor too hard. Some of them can even be solved in multiple ways, which I felt was a nice touch and shows how much thought was put into making this game. A developer commentary is included, giving further insight into the authors' minds. There are some visual bugs, but nothing gamebreaking.  Overall a very enjoyable game, even if you're not a fan of the genre. Definitely worth the price tag.
Highly recommended. Thats all.
I am not into puzzle games, but this one got my attention. Finished it with thinking that my time was not wasted.

Awesome cyberpunk adventure game. Engaging storyline, amazing atmosphere, nice pixel art, great pacing, logical puzzles and a good blend of action segments make this one of the best adventure game out there.

This is probably the best dark sci-fi adventure game in recent years. I played this on my IPAD month ago. On PC, I buy it again.   This old school style game with the mystery plots, the voice and the dark ambient space music are incredibly amazing. Don't be fooled by the graphics .this game is really good .the old school graphics make this game better.

I just finished it, and it was good. Very Beneath a Steel Sky-esque, with a hint of Full Throttle (I'm not even sure why, but some parts of GR reminded me of some parts of FT). I really liked Gemini Rue.  It is not exempt from a few shortcomings: the controls and interface kinda suck, combat is God awful (not even sure why they felt the need to include combat at all: it really feels out of place), everyone relevant lives in the same one condo, there are not that many locations in the game.  But the good stuff vastly surpasses those. The atmosphere is just great, the visual design is excellent (hand-drawn, visible sketch lines, watercolour-y backdrops, big pixels for character sprints), the story flows well and the dialogue is quite well-written. The plot 'twist' is introduced/hinted decently, and the 'converging stories' device is also used fairly well. The music and voice acting also are top notch.  Overall, Gemini Rue feels old school as ♥♥♥♥, in every respect: it is a greatly atmospheric and utterly enjoyable game that would have worked perfectly in 1994 as it does now.

This is a great sci-fi noir point-and-click adventure game, and I recommend it to anyone with an interest in that sort of thing. The highest praise I can give it is that while not all of the puzzles are easily resolved, after finishing the more difficult ones I found myself saying, 'Oh, of course,' rather than 'What the hell?' It has good logic and excellent design. The only downside is that there are a few repetitive puzzles that go on for longer than they need to, but even these make sense within the story. It's a good play; pick it up!

Good stuff. It's got a cool sci fi vibe that's similar to Blade Runner and The Island.  Obviously it has the slightly annoying solutions that so many of these games have (I had to follow a guide a few times), but it's easier to follow than many of the other adventure games I've played.
A little slow, but still enjoyable.  7/10  Whatatweest

Pros: Fantastic music and sound, good art Cons: Story ends predictably, the philosophy is sophomoric and telegraphed, the art obfuscates about a third of the puzzle click points, the combat system is incredibly frustrating, and autosaves occur waaaay before those combats occur.

Very nice game which is obviously trying very hard to draw parallels with both 'Beneath a Steel Sky' and 'Blade Runner'. Storywise it's up there with the very best of sci-fi gaming, with plenty of mystery, intrigue and plot twists where you least expect them. It's very beautiful to look at, in a VGA sort of way....and the sound design is top notch too. I know some people didn't care for the voice acting but it seemed fine to me. Even if the 'grizzled hardboiled' protagonist sounds like Harvey Fierstein imitating Marlon Brando :D  Unfortunately the interface is needlessly cumbersome. Rather than, say, left-click to look and right-click to use like the aforementioned Sky which they so liberally borrow from, you have to right-click, choose which part of your body you want to use to interact with an item and then click on it. It gets even more complicated when you gain a sidekick and have to drag them around in the same way. If you come across a ladder, do you use your foot or your hand on it? Actually, either works, but why give us the choice? 'Use' really should be context-appropriate nowadays as most of the choices the player is given are either stupid (You're not going to use your mouth on the ladder) or don't matter (hand or foot works)....  Oh, points also deducted for introducing a needless real-time combat system. Adventure games don't need real-time combat. I thought we learned this with Harvester, Blade Runner, Maddog Williams....at least Full Throttle let you skip the arcade sections if you didn't want to do them....
Story - 12/10  The best click and point adventure game ever  The plot twist and 'Holy sh*t' reaction will never get you off
gud game m8, worth a few squid from mummy's debit card.
A great modern day, point and click adventure. Had fun every minute. Worth picking up no matter what the price is.

Gemini Rue is a point and click adventure game with sparse and limited fighting mechanics in various stages of the game that takes place in a dystopian sci-fi future that could be inspired easily from movies like Blade Runner. As it is expected, you explore the environment and interact with people and objects in order to solve puzzles and eventually proceed. There is also an item called the communicator which lets you communicate with various characters throughout the game but also provides you with all the necessary information and mission status.  You play the role of a man named Azriel who was an ex assassin but now has left his past behind him and works as an officer against the organized crime which is run by a mafia-like group called the Boryokudan. Your formal mission is to aid a man who later helps you on your true mission which is to acquire information about your lost brother Daniel. After infiltrating the Boryokudans and reaviling that there is a secret facility where people are sent there to have their memory whipped out and re-trained to become criminals and that your brother was sent there, you gather your crew and set a new mission, rescuing your brother.   The storyline despite being short is quite compelling and there are nice twists at the end as expected. The overall theme of the game is nicely expressed through the art style with retro like graphics and atmospheric music. However, I would really prefer it if instead the 16 bit overlay the visuals were a little more detailed. In comparison, the audio quality is really impressive for being an indie game. The audio logs are rich and clearly there was put a lot of effort into it. So, the audio and visuals are not side by side in my opinion.   All in all, Gemini Rue is a solid adventure game following the steps of the classic ones, yet it feels fresh and modernized. All friends of the adventure genre should definitely try out this game.

Bought this version for easier playing, I'm experiencing constant crashes. Too bad, because I got really interested in the android version, will have to finish this using the etch-a-sketch, if at all.

2D point-and-click noir adventure game about the nature of man. I can't say much else about the game without spoilers, but it is a dark and gritty space tale that jumps between two characters. Definitely worth checking out If you enjoy older adventure games like King's Quest & Monkey Island.
You don't have to live a life of rue anymore.

In all honesty...  *THE* best game I've played in like 15+ years. I really don't think kids these days <shakes fist> will understand its beauty, but it returns to its roots with strong storytelling and gameplay. The graphics are retro-awesome, with gritty cyberpunk/dystopian environments.   Seriously, buy this game!
This game makes my head hurts

If you're a fan of Bladerunner, Cowboy Bebop, Firefly, even Mass Effect, then this game is for you. It's a neo-noir futuristic cyberpunk point-and-click adventure where you play as an Investigator called Azriel Oden (ex assassin). He is on a mission to find his brother who he hasn't talked to in 10 years. Ugh, so much is going through my mind right now, even a bit depressed... All I have to say is that this game is a 10/10 Game of the Year of All Years.

The writing on this is ridiculously horrible. While the broad strokes--narrative, character--are simply weak, the basic grasp of language and grammar was horrific to the point of pain. Couldn't get past it, and the puzzles certainly didn't make up for it.
Rating 2/10. Avoid.   The Good:

Everything about this game stinks of plagiarism from Phillip K. ♥♥♥♥, and films based on his work (Blade Runner and Total Recall in particular), but the narrative and dialogue lack any sense of subtlety. The writer apparently hasn't got an original thought in his head, but is very impressed with himself for having passed Philosophy 101. For a game that makes a big deal about free will, it's kind of ironic that there are literally no choices to be made, no story branches, nothing that you can do that will affect the plot in the slightest. At least most of the visuals are nice.   The puzzles are mostly pretty straightforward once you acquire the necessary items and information, but there's a lot of plodding around just picking up random crap wondering where it will come in handy. There are maps of a city that you're in for much of the game, but you can't even explore most of what it shows- you're a cop chasing leads, and literally everyone lives in TWO apartment buildings.  The game is also plagued by some serious bugs, which for some users could prevent them from running it at all, or cause crashes that prevent further progress. It took me quite a bit of research just to get it running, and then a lot of trial and error to get past one such bug, but I did manage to make it to the end. Not particularly glad I did. It's all very predictable, and incredibly preachy. Not recommended.
High-graphics are blurry bull-♥♥♥♥, low-graphics are a pixelated mess.  On top of that it's boring garbage, like every 2d point-and-click adventure ever made.

Excellent science fiction point-and-click adventure. Almost as good as Resonance. Both games had wonderful stories, but Gemini Rue was more traditional in terms of gameplay, and the puzzles were simpler. Still, I recommend anyone check out Gemini Rue if you like smart, stylish science fiction.
Incredible addition to the old school point & click adventure genre, and the noir theme is just icing on the cake. Think blade runner meets dollhouse.

What an amazing game. The music, the atmosphere, the 640x480 8 bit graphics, it feels like a classic point-and-click adventure game with modern music and voice acting. The best part is that I could play the game with only using a few hints - usually I can't finish adventure games without using a ton of hints or a walkthrough and that ruins the experience for me.  The only downside is that it's not a very long game, this game leaves me wanting more...  I have two tips for any new players. Tip one: play this game using the highest Nearest Neighbor scaling that supports your monitor resolution, to keep the blocky pixelated look. Also do not use the high quality sprite shading, it scales the sprites to a resolution that doesn't match the surrounding environment and it looks out of place.  Tip two: make sure to check every detail in a scene when you're stuck, usually the clue is right there.

Fanatstic futuristic point and click adventure. The graphics are very 16-bit-ish, but I relly loved it. The story was well balanced, and the puzzles were not too hard. A great game, worth every dollar. There was not much music going on unfortunatly. And the shoot elements felt unnecessary.
Great game with really interesting story.
An awesome old-skool adventure game that is similar to Blade Runner. I highly recommend this even though there is some annoying pixel hunting. 9/10
Fantastic old-school adventure with great narration and plenty of style. Great for anyone who enjoyed classic point-and-click adventure games and/or Blade Runner.

Above average point and click adventure game. The voice acting is pretty strong for the most part and the puzzles are challenging but not insurmountable...I think I may have only needed to look up a solution once, or maybe twice. The game is fairly short and can finished in roughly 8 hours. Gemini Rue is definitely worth the buy at $10 or less.
Back to the future! Interesting click puzzle advanture game, whith ncie story and twist.
Blade Runner. Adventure. Pixels. - If you like these things Gemini Rue is for you
almost as good as Blade Runner!

The story in this game is pretty good and I really like the art style. I had some trouble on some of the puzzles in the second half of the game but most werent bad. Voice acting is hit or miss, some characters are really good. I'd recommend for the story alone

Partly clunky controlling of characters and unnecessary rudimentary shooting 'combat' which needed to be improved much more (or removed).  Another annoyance is that prior to a combat, there should be a auto-save which skip the dialogues, in case one dies, so that you don't have to walk back and click through the dialogue again, which get reaaaaally old pretty quick.  Other issues are the typical point&click issues like cryptic riddles or random combination of item, or the random order of actions which have to take place, which is luckily not thaaaat bad in GR, but still annoying.  Beside all that, the game is really good and I would recommend it. Fortunately the writing is much better than most other philosophically touched games and the visuals are beautiful for fans of old school p&c adventures.

What agreat game. as with all games in the mechanical genre, it rests its weight on the story, and for a noir story, this one is REALLY GOOD. thje developer commentary is ashore, since it needs a complete re-play. I'll just youtube it.

I had a lot of fun playing this game. For some reason I though this is a new release of an old game on steam.  It has a great vibe, it can make you believe that you're actually in the story despite the lack of fancy graphics or movement.  Recommended for anyone who likes slow point and click games.  Pro tip: if you're stuck, you probably missed something on the screen. Just keep hovering that mouse over everything!

This game has the visuals of an old school adventure, think of the old Indiana Jones or Monkey Island titles.   What I liked was the serious approach, no jokes and stuff (well nearly), the good soundtrack and the unusual control mechanisms (fighting e.g., haven't seen that in a point-and-click adventure). You have to get used to them though.  But where the game really shines is the great story, it really took me and I didn't see much of it coming. In my opinion it has a better story than comparably big adventure titles!

Great fun. Awesome little noir game that is definetly worth the $10. This game not only has a really awesome story but the graphics and the time put into making them mesh gave me giant retro-boners. Made me want to start playing Police Quest again (not the VGA titles).

Pretty cool game. It takes a little bit of thinking though, so if your not good at that its probably not for you. You play as a guy named Azriel trying to save his brother from a government facility, and as the brother Delta-Six on the facility. Azriel, an ex-assasin turned cop, has to go through the local mafia to find where his brother is. Meanwhile Delta-Six is executing and escape plan to get out. Will the brothers finaly be reunited? Wel... you'll just have to find out.  Lots of puzzles, great story and some nice background music to set the mood. There might be a twist, or there might not. Play the game and see.
This will make you belive in adventure games again.

If you're looking for some old-school PNC adventure, this game is fantastic. It had very little involvement from Wadjet beyond voice talent and portriats, but ultimately came from one dude. It even has some fun gunplay. Plus, switching between two characters at will is an interesting mechanic.
Classic stylings and great voice acting. Has a really great Orweliian or Scott Card feel for it. I'd pick it up if you like point and clicks.
Really great point&click with nostalgic feel. Blade Runner is one of your favorite movies? You know what to do...
A great story based point and click adventure. Great Dystopian art and plot. Would highly recomend.

Above average point and click adventure game. The voice acting is pretty strong for the most part and the puzzles are challenging but not insurmountable...I think I may have only needed to look up a solution once, or maybe twice. The game is fairly short and can finished in roughly 8 hours. Gemini Rue is definitely worth the buy at $10 or less.

Another great adventure game from Wadjet Eye. The story, atmosphere and voice acting are great in Gemini Rue. The puzzels are logical with just the right amount of difficulty. Definitely check it out if you are a point and click adventure fan, or you just like a good story.

Gemini Rue is an old-school point and click adventure game with some action elements. The game has an involving story and unusually good use of pixelated retro graphics but is somewhat on the easy side.  The game is set in a dystopian future and features a story that starts our mysterious and gradually reveals more about what is going on. The story has philosophical aspects touching on the relationship between memories and personal identity although it doesn't really explore the subjects in any great detail. The story is the best aspect of the game and is helped by the fact that there are two branches of the story unravelling at the same, the two of which later converge. I found the story very appealing and it kept me wanting to keep playing to find out what would happen.  The pixelated graphics suit the atmosphere of the game very well and the visuals are nicely done. I think pixelated graphics have been overused in recent times, but here they are used to good effect.  Sound effects are adequate but nothing special, voice acting on the other hand is considerably above average and matches the personalities of the characters well.  The actual gameplay is the weakest aspect of the game. Puzzles are somewhat bland, not all that creative and mostly a bit too easy. The action sequences are nothing special and don't add much to the game. You could perhaps argue that in a strongly story driven game like this, having easy puzzles may be a good thing, as harder puzzles would only be frustrating when you want to make progress to find out how the story continues. Whether or not you accept that arugment I think that the somewhat lackluster gameplay pulls the game down a bit and keeps it from being the really great game that it could have been.  All in all this is a highly recommended game for all point and click adventure enthusiasts, ar least if you think a good well-told story is at least as important as good gameplay.
A great story based point and click adventure. Great Dystopian art and plot. Would highly recomend.

Scifi point and click adventure game; good story, characters, voice-acting, graphics, pacing, gameplay. Puzzles reasonable and I never truly felt stuck anywhere. Has a combat system that works reasonably smoothly and reminds me a little bit of Blackthorne or 'Another World'. Twist at the end. Solid and worth playing.

A great throwback to the adventure games of old. As with any adventure game worth its salt, the game draws you in with an engaging story, a rich cyberpunk atmosphere, and a fitting Bladerunner/Noir-style soundtrack. The game play is your typical point and click with puzzles that compliment the story instead of just being obtuse puzzles for the sake of having puzzles. The user interface and inventory management is very user friendly and doesn't require copious amounts of mouse waving and clicking. The game will roughly last you 4-6 hours depending on how puzzle-saavy you are.  If you do plan of purchasing Gemini Rue, I highly reccomend you play with the voices turned off your first time through. Some characters can come off as very stilted and cheesey and can take away from an otherwise immersive experience. Unless you absolutely cannot stand reading in games, the voices are best left to the imagination.

What an amazing game. The music, the atmosphere, the 640x480 8 bit graphics, it feels like a classic point-and-click adventure game with modern music and voice acting. The best part is that I could play the game with only using a few hints - usually I can't finish adventure games without using a ton of hints or a walkthrough and that ruins the experience for me.  The only downside is that it's not a very long game, this game leaves me wanting more...  I have two tips for any new players. Tip one: play this game using the highest Nearest Neighbor scaling that supports your monitor resolution, to keep the blocky pixelated look. Also do not use the high quality sprite shading, it scales the sprites to a resolution that doesn't match the surrounding environment and it looks out of place.  Tip two: make sure to check every detail in a scene when you're stuck, usually the clue is right there.

It's a definate old school game, but maybe one that wouldn't have been appriciated as much back then due to philospohical questions, but still enjoyable none the less with a fully voice acted dialogue and enjoyable game. Don't expect joypad friendly UI, just classic interface you can smash your face on.

Just started playing, loving it so far, reminds me of the old classic 'Future Wars' from Delphine Software.... Point and click adventure game with some action/combat scenes.... More games like this please,  FPS and RTS games have flooded the market.... But good old point and click (or back in the day, Text) adventures are the greatest and what got me into computers when I was 5.
REALLY GOOD GAME 9/10  Good atmosphere, good story, good characters, just go ahead and play it! If you love point and click adventures, you MUST play Gemini Rue!

I stumbled upon this when I was looking for an adventure game with an intriguing story, which is what I found and I'm glad I did.  Gemini Rue is a noir science fiction retro point and click adventure with a twist. The first part of the game lets you switch between two characters: A cop with a dark past trying to find his brother, and a brainwashed prisoner trying to escape a rehabilitation facility. The second part is the well executed conclusion of both of those stories.  The setting and ambience fit the overall theme very nicely, and the game does well in making you care for what happens to the characters.  The rare combat sequences are fun and don't feel, as one might fear in a point & click adventure, out of place at all. The soundtrack and voice acting is great too.   Everyone looking for a serious, thought-provoking story in the form of an adventure game should not ignore this gem, which is my new favorite non-comedic point and click.
Classic, oldfashioned adventure, with a deep atmosphere and many elements of Blade Runner in it. Loved it to play!

A faily easy adventure game even for a non-expert like me. Despite the lovely art which evokes the golden era of the game genre que main atraction here is the crispy writing along side a story that ends with a awesome plot twist.

This is what Bladerunner game should have looked like if it was made old school. It's just awesome i had to beat it twice. The soundtrack is worth the purchase too. Best indie adventure game i've ever bought. Plus you can't ruin yourself for such a low price. I wish steam would release 'The Shivah' from the same dev.
For the love of god. Don't miss out on this little gem. Very inspiring and very mind blowing, if you like Inception as well as a point and click, you'll love this game.
one of the best indie sci-fi ive played. has a great storyline and reminds me a lot of the blade runner film,
Great little Point n' Click adventure.   Cool story. Cool characters. Cool atmostphere.
Well bought 4 backlog, good story. One of the best pk adventure in recent time. Actually give that piece of art more credit. Buy & Try.
Brilliant. Amazing old-fashioned point-and-click with great story writing. Absolutely worth playing.

This game is excellent, and now drives me to beg for another installment in the same universe.  Similar in tone and execution to Cowboy Bebop, this point-and-click basic puzzle-solver gives a vibrant and gritty worldspace to the players. It also executes an AMAZING story with succinct story-telling and attaches you to the characters that you interact with. The puzzles are easy, the combat is quite thrilling for a point-and-click, and the art style is basic - though it performs admirably.  This is one of the better games of recent times that has had puzzle elements and exploration, and its narrative was deserving of a $60 Triple-A title.  I highly encourage anyone who can look past the basic graphics to enjoy the game! Enjoy a world of sci-fi through a personal adventure of characters Azriel Odin and the unfortunate Delta-Six both. Explore a world of advanced technology that drives one to question humanity and experience. Dive into gang dens and post war cities, as well as a sterile training facility guided by a disembodied voice of The Director.  Also, when in doubt - kick it.

I picked it up because I was buying some games on Steam, didn't know much about it and I didn't expect much from it.  What I got was something completely different to what I expected! The story is mind blowing, the puzzles are as they always should be in a point and click, however the combat is a terribly weak part of the game (thankfully there are only a small number of combat sections in the game) and it isn't without bugs, but for such a small team to create this...  I know I haven't said much about the plot, but I'm not going to. Play it for yourself, playing it without knowing anything is the best way to play it.

Great story  The gunfights are, even though simple on normal level, a nice touch.  The story and carachters feel real, and the dialouges are nicely done.  It is a little bit too short in relation to the price, but its a quality product
A brilliant masterpiece, as a piece of sci-fi storytelling, as a game, and most of all, in the way that it articulates both these things together. A game to be remembered.
Cool story, yo
Wardjeteye games makes unusual PaC adventure games in an old 8-bit style but they all are very story rich. Besides Primordia and monkey island this is the best PaC i played

***First and foremost: turn off ehanced pointer precision from the windows control panel (if its enabled) and turn off 'smooth scaled sprites' from the game's config menu. There is atrocious input lag from the mouse if not done but it's an easy one time fix.***  I had never played a point-and-click adventure game in this kind of style, which seems to have been quite big in the early days of the PC gaming era. What caught my eye in the trailer for it was a very atmospheric and cinematic game. Despite some bugs that may take some googling to get around, the game seems to deliver on those advertised aspects. I'm suprised at how engaging the voice acting can be and the general moodiness it puts you in.   The gun combat isn't that great, and in some stealth scenarios it's not very intuitive that the enemy could see you from such a distance, but I think the game allows for enough trial-and-error that it doesn't get in the way of the better parts of the experience.  The writing and atmosphere of the game are great. The graphics are a little dated, but that might be the aesthetic the devs were going for. Higher resolution options would have been a welcome addition. The game's story is interesting and engaging. Some of the game interactions may be a bit buggy or unintuitive for today's audiences, but gamers that are very familiar with the quirks of point-and-click adventure games will feel right at home.
Three words: Wadjet Eye Games.
I am enjoying the story and the atmosphere the game has.

Inspired by classic adventure games of the 90's, Gemini Rue is a noire sci-fi tale with enough twists and turns to keep the player guessing before the pieces of plot fall into place for a satisfying 'uh-hu' moment.  If you enjoyed playing Kings Quest, Space Quest and similar adventure games from the 90's, you wont be dissapointed.
A fun cyberpunk noir oldschool adventure game.

Taken from the style of the 1980s and 90;s prepare to go back to dos land, although its a modern voice acting and greaat story makes this game a must play for anyone that loves the Noire style story with a scifi feel. its worth buying.
